This company is all about continuous improvement - if something needs to be done you have to be ready to figure it out. pros: The job is pretty easy. you usually start as either a pallet jack driver or forklift. The base starting pay is 13.55/hour with the potential to make an extra 2$ if you go over the 85% goal. They have 3 different shifts you can start on, but usually hire most for 2nd or 3rd to start.
cons: Cold storage, so if you dont like the cold, dont bother. coldest room is about -30F. Warmest is about 40F. Seems to be somewhat ruled by favoritism. You must make and maintain a percent goal of 85%. This is easy to maintain in some departments of the warehouse, and impossible in others.

title: Good Experience but...
pros: I love working at Lineage, but like all companies of its size, it depends on the location. At my facility, the management is engaged with employees and dedicated to safety, quality, and improvement. They train employees and generally promote from within when new positions become available. Starting pay is great at our plant, and there is opportunity for growth within the company.
cons: Lineage is a growing company, and they are experiencing growing pains. Both service and employee experiences are inconsistent across the facilities. Corporate is not the easiest to deal with.

title: Incompetent and inefficient
pros: It's a paycheck. And you can get some experience working with pallet jacks and forklifts which you can use elsewhere. Benefits are a bit better than you'd expect from a low paying job like this, as well.
cons: Where to start? Management's lack of communication with each other, lack of communication with employees, dirty and snide remarks behind employee's backs, lack of proper training programs. You can look forward to all this and more when working here. Routinely throwing boxes heavier than 60+ pounds, hand wrapping pallets with no equipment to make that more ergonomic or comfortable. Terrible sight lines for the equipment operators. And what's more, the company requires -you- to call -them- to ask if you work overtime if it's needed.

title: Receiving Operator
pros: -Easy work -Managers and Leads appreciate honest and hard workers and reward them for it -Work hard, have a good career here - Co-workers are exceptionally friendly - starting pay is $13.50 after 6 months or so I was given a .70 cent raise and another .70 after a year. - I've been her a little over a year and my manager already tells me I'm in a position to move up quickly - hours are long sometimes, but a lot of times, just as long as you work at s steady pace and stay on task it's very possible to get off on time if not a little earlier. -Management cares about their employees. Benefits are affordable, considering your rate of pay
cons: -Attendance is 99.9% the determining factor in wether or not you get a raise during your yearly review (regardless of how high you score in all other categories) -Days are long sometimes, and managers ask employees to work overtime the next day, less than 24 hours in advance, and don't like when you say no. -If initiative isn't shown, leads and management will use you mostly for difficult and strenuous tasks all while the favorites get to take a walk in the park and go home early - Small parking lot, have to park out on street in a red zone if you show up too late. -If you forget your jacket or neck warmer, prepare to be in for a long and uncomfortably cold night. -Some employees have no regard for other forklift drivers when meneuvering around the doc (If you're not aware or stay alert YOU WILL have an accident and undergo a drug test and possibly termination depending on severity *GOOD OUTWEIGHS THE BAD* *HIGHLY RECOMMENDED*

title: Hiring Line & Firing Line

cons: Regardless of the work load, you're expected to be done counting freezer aisles in 8 hrs. Unless you're the a lead, they can sit on the cpu and stay as long as they like.

I have only been with Lineage for a year and have already met with so many different leaders to discuss my development whether it's in the company or somewhere else. They truly care for their employees and understand work life balance. You don't find that in many companies so it's a sigh of relief to be apart of a company that does.
cons: The company is growing so fast the supporting departments can't keep up. They are working on getting more support and do handle issues quickly that arise.

title: Transportation Administrative Support
pros: For me this job was close to home, ok benefits, and my hours were good the pros stop with that.
cons: I was told this was a stressful job. The job itself was easy, the people in the department were what caused the stress. Evil, hateful people who are so unhappy with their own lives that they have nothing better to do than be mean and hurtful to fellow employees. Not my opinion alone, the department is a revolving door.

The company will nickel & dime you every time they can, by finding reasons, & opportunities to pay you bottom of the barrel wages, only 50% match on 401k.; wages that make it almost impossible to pay bill's, and live off of. Building any type of savings is impossible.

title: Work

title: Find A Better Option!
pros: I think they may have finally hit rock bottom so things can only improve.....right??

Purchase highly profitable business, come in and pump sunshine up everyones booty about how great Lineage is and how much they are going to improve things. "YEAH Lineage!!" Step 2. Bring in senior managers who have zero refrigerated warehousing experience. Sounds sketchy but we'll go with it. These guys worked on Wall Street surely they're smart? Step 3. "Get outta here with all your knowledge and ideas that have been proven to work!" Step 6. Finally realize that huge mistakes were made in hiring such underqualified managers. Also realize that all of the experienced managers have left or been fired. Oops! Fire senior managers. Little bit late but can't cry over spilled milk. Step 7. Totally abandon the Lean initiative and just focus on customer satisfaction. Wait, what's that? You say all of the people who actually knew how to run the facility are gone? How did that happen, lol. Out of town support, corporate troubleshooters, visual aids, corporate power meetings, you name it. Step 9. Realize that all of your money cannot buy success and deal with the sad fact that customers responsible for most of your profits just gave you the finger and you now have to lay off over 50% of your workforce. Step 10. Bring in big dog regional managers to give a pep talk. Start pumping that sunshine again. "Trust us" they say, lol. Strategize about how you can hide the failures of the largest, most profitable location you had. Maybe buy some more smaller companies? Under no circumstances discuss how and why it all went bad in the matter of 3-4 short years. Step 11. Head back to the brand new shiny corporate office. Maybe catch some waves? I mean.....you deserve it with all those successful business decisions and all ;-)

title: Committed Supervisors Struggling to Navigate a Challenging, Understaffed Environment
pros: Supportive Supervisors: The immediate leadership at the supervisor level genuinely cares about their teams and tries to do their best with the resources they are given. Opportunities for Growth: If you are proactive about your development, there are opportunities to learn and grow, especially with exposure to different areas of the logistics process. Stable Industry: Lineage Logistics is well-positioned in a growing industry, offering job stability for those looking for long-term employment.
cons: Burnout and Unrealistic Expectations: Staff are often overburdened with tasks and expected to meet unrealistic productivity goals without adequate resources or support. As a result, burnout is common, and employee well-being can sometimes take a backseat to performance metrics. Toxic Work Environment: A lack of collaboration between management levels sometimes leads to a toxic atmosphere. Managers avoid addressing underlying issues to prevent conflict with others, which causes frustration and disengagement among staff. There seems to be little accountability at higher levels for the struggles faced by employees on the ground. Limited Support for Teams: While supervisors often try to advocate for their teams, they are frequently overruled by upper management, making it difficult for them to effect meaningful change. This creates a disconnect between staff and leadership and leaves supervisors in a difficult position of looking like the ones failing their teams, even when they are powerless to make necessary changes.

title: Fix it
pros: One of the reasons I work at lineage is because the shift patterns are some of the best I've worked, I get plenty of time off work so I'm not constantly stressed with work. The job itself is not bad at all, it takes a good while to get to a good level with it but once your comfortable it's a doddle. I quite enjoy working with my colleagues on shift since we crack on with the job and we have a good laugh with each other whilst we do it, supervisors and the manager are all good fun to work for and don't belittle you like a lot of higher-ups do in a lot of places, they treat you fairly and respectfully.
cons: There's quite a bit of frustration with three things for me which is communication, mhe and ppe. I feel that things aren't always communicated very well which can get very frustrating since I may be unaware of for instance a change to how we book in stock for a certain customer. My second issue is with the general quality and lack of care when it comes to mhe, the amount of truck's that are not running properly or aren't running at all is frankly ridiculous, I believe all this could be less of an issue if equipment was regularly serviced to reduce chances of them breaking down, I understand sometimes equipment breaks down but it does become rather problematic when multiple trucks are non functional. My third issue is that the ppe quality leaves a lot to be desired in particular the gloves that are provided, they need to provide better quality gloves particularly for people that work in the freezer, your can't last very long in the store with gloves that don't provide enough protection for the cold conditions as such this needs to be addressed.
